channel.title: Social Psychology: Theory & Method (Autumn 2025)
channel.description: Lecture recordings, discussions, and seminar highlights from the Autumn 2025 Social Psychology: Theory & Method course.
channel.itunes:author: Thomas Morton and teaching team

item.title: Week 40 · Making Sense of the Social World
item.description: We look at attribution and social cognition—how people explain behaviour, encode group information, and challenge stereotypes—drawing on Sutton & Douglas (Chs. 3, 11 & 12), Heider’s naïve analysis, Weiner on motivation, and contemporary prejudice research.

item.title: Week 39 · The Social Self and Intergroup Identity
item.description: This session examines how dynamic self-concepts emerge from group memberships, featuring Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 2) alongside Tajfel & Turner’s social identity theory and seminar work on Activity 1.

item.title: Week 38 · Conformity, Obedience, and Resistance
item.description: Classic studies by Asch, Milgram, and Zimbardo anchor a discussion of group processes, power, and resistance, complemented by Haslam & Reicher's reinterpretation of conformity and Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 9).

item.title: Week 37 · Connections, Crowds, and the Need to Belong
item.description: We explore how other people shape individual psychology through crowd processes, depersonalisation, and bystander dynamics, foregrounding Baumeister & Leary on the need to belong, Hopkins et al. on solidarity in crowds, and Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 10).

item.title: Week 36 · Introduction to Social Psychology
item.description: Thomas Morton opens the Autumn 2025 course with the history, scope, and controversies of social psychology, drawing on Sutton & Douglas (Ch. 1), Doise & Valentim's levels of analysis, Gergen's call to treat the field as history, and the Open Science Collaboration's reproducibility findings.
